rows.title: Skipping Rope Song

This energetic game builds coordination, confidence, and teamwork. ğŸŒˆ

steps_text.eng:

2ï¸âƒ£ Two people turn the rope while one jumps in the middle.

ğŸ† You can add fun moves like hopping, clapping, or even dancing while skipping. 

ğŸ’› Then switch places so everyone gets a turn.

rows.title: Round & Round

intro_text.eng:
Letâ€™s make a circle, sing, and get moving with some fun and silly moves! ğŸ¶ 

This activity builds connection, encourages coordination and balance, and sparks lots of laughter and creativity ğŸ˜ƒ

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ‘‹ Grab each otherâ€™s hands and form a circle. 

ğŸµ Walk round and round while you sing a song you know - it could be one from your childhood like â€œRing-a-Rosyâ€ or â€œSawa Sonkeâ€, or a favourite your child loves. 

ğŸ‰ As you go round, add some silly moves to make it even more fun. Try hopping on one leg, see if you can put your leg over the next personâ€™s arm, or gently fall to the ground when the song finishes. 

ğŸ”„ Take turns choosing the next move or song!

rows.title: Can You Catch It?

intro_text.eng:
Letâ€™s see if you can follow instructions while catching a ball! âš½ 

This activity is a great way to improve coordination, concentration, and quick thinking - all while having fun! ğŸ’¡

steps_text.eng:
âœ… Start by standing about three metres apart and gently throw a ball at each other. After a few easy throws, itâ€™s time to introduce the rules!

1ï¸âƒ£ When the thrower shouts â€˜oneâ€™, the catcher has to catch the ball with their right hand and put their left foot out. 

2ï¸âƒ£ If the thrower shouts â€˜twoâ€™, the catcher catches with their left hand and puts their right foot out.

â­ Once youâ€™re confident, add some extra numbers and rules! 

â° For the game to work, make sure the number is called before you throw the ball, so the catcher has time to react!

tips_text.eng: ğŸš© You can adjust the rules to make it perfect for every age.

rows.title: Unseen Guesses

intro_text.eng:
You can do this activity when you are together with at least three people in total. 3ï¸âƒ£  

This game is not only fun but also helps children develop strong communication skills and teaches them how to work together to achieve a goal. ğŸ’š

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ‘€ Ask your child and another child/adult to sit next to each other. Blindfold both using a scarf or hat. 

ğŸš— Give your child an object and ask them to feel it and describe it, without saying the name of the object!

ğŸ The other personâ€™s job is to figure out what the object is based on the description. 

âœ… The â€œguesserâ€ can ask questions, but the â€œspeakerâ€ can only answer with "yes" or "no".

ğŸ”„ After each round, swap roles and play again, giving everyone a chance to be the â€œspeakerâ€ and â€œguesserâ€ and the one to provides the object.

rows.title: A Friendly Chat

intro_text.eng:
Want to connect with your teen? Start by talking about what they care about! ğŸ˜ƒ

These small chats can lead to stronger connections and bigger conversations down the road.ğŸ‘‚â¤ï¸

steps_text.eng: âš½ An easy way to start talking to your teen is to ask them about something they are interested in. For example, you could talk about sports, books, movies, friends, music, celebrities, or school.

tips_text.eng: ğŸ‘‚ You may not find everything your teen shares to be interesting, but itâ€™s important to show enthusiasm and an eagerness to learn.

rows.title: Reflect on the Positive

intro_text.eng:
Looking for a simple way to boost your mood and connect as a family? Try this quick daily check-in! ğŸŒˆ

Sharing positive moments - big or small - helps everyone feel more grateful and supported.

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ’¡ Together, take a minute to think about all the things you did today. 

â˜€ï¸ Take turns sharing one positive or fun thing that happened. This could be something small, like feeling good because you cleaned the house, or something big, like spending time with family and friends. 

â° Try doing this every day - even more on the days it feels like you have not done anything special.

rows.title: Check-in Chat

intro_text.eng: Actively checking in on one another helps to keep relationships healthy! â­

steps_text.eng:
Ask each other questions: 
ğŸ‘‚ğŸ¾ â€œWhat made you happy today?â€ 
ğŸ’› â€œWhat was difficult today?â€  
ğŸ«¶ğŸ¾ â€œHow can I help you?â€

rows.title: Weekly Goal Setting

intro_text.eng:
Setting goals together is a great way to build confidence and stay motivated! â­

Weekly goals are small steps that help you and your teen grow - one week at a time. ğŸ‰

steps_text.eng:
1. â­ At the start of the week, help your teen set one specific and achievable goal.
2. ğŸ¤ Share your own goal too - support each other throughout the week.
3. ğŸ‰ Praise your teenâ€™s effort and celebrate their progress.
4. ğŸ’¬ If they donâ€™t reach their goal, talk about what happened and how to try again next time.

tips_text.eng: ğŸ” Make this a weekly habit to build confidence and success step by step!

rows.title: Role play

intro_text.eng:
Letâ€™s start acting! â­

Role-playing is when you pretend to be someone in a certain situation, and act out how you think things will go. 

This is a fun way to help your teen understand how others might act or feel, and for you to learn more about how your teen thinks and feels. âœ¨

steps_text.eng:
1. ğŸ˜Š Ask your teen if theyâ€™d like to try a fun â€œrole-playingâ€ game with you.
2. ğŸ­ Let them choose a situation to act out - it could be something from school or even social media. For example, playing a teacher and student, or a teen being offered a drink at a party.
3. ğŸ¬ Let your teen decide who plays each role, and act it out together!
4. ğŸ’¬ After the role-play, talk about what you both learned. Ask questions like, â€œHow did that feel?â€ or â€œWhat did you notice about the situation?â€ This helps your teen understand different perspectives and emotions.

rows.title: Make Housework Fun

intro_text.eng:
Turn your chores into games! ğŸ† 

Making housework fun is a good way to teach your teen to be responsible and to rely on themselves. â˜€ï¸

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ“ Together, make a list of all the chores that must be done in your home. 

ğŸ’¡ Make sure the tasks are fair and things your teen can do. For example, washing up, sweeping, mopping, making the beds, and laundry.

ğŸ”„ Each week, let a different person in the family choose a chore first.

ğŸµ Play some music or turn on the radio. Music is a great way to make a boring task fun!

âœ… Tick off the tasks when they are done so you can see your progress as a family. 
ğŸ“º You could offer small rewards as motivation to complete activities. For example, you could let your teen watch more TV or have something sweet if they do their chores in a fair amount of time.

tips_text.eng: â“ If your child does not complete a chore, ask them why, and come up with a fair consequence together.

rows.title: Gardening

steps_text.eng:
ğŸŒ¿ Choose plants: Let your teen pick veggies or herbs to grow - theyâ€™ll love being involved and can help cook them later!

ğŸª´ Get creative: No garden? No problem! Use old buckets, cans, or bottles as plant pots.

ğŸ‰ Plant together: Turn planting into a fun â€œplanting partyâ€ - take turns putting seeds in the soil.

ğŸ’§ Care routine: Make a watering schedule and let your teen take charge of their plants.

ğŸ“ Track growth: Each week, have your teen note the changes and see how much the plants have grown!

rows.title: Charades

intro_text.eng: Charades is an easy, fun game that will teach your teen to think quickly, work together and be bold. ğŸ­

steps_text.eng:
1. ğŸ¤« One person quietly thinks of a word but doesnâ€™t say it out loud to anyone.

2. ğŸ­ That person then acts out the word using only actions - no speaking, sounds, or pointing to objects.

3. ğŸ§¹ Others try to guess what the word is! You can choose fun everyday actions like sweeping, eating, playing football, or brushing teeth.

4. âœ… When someone guesses correctly, it becomes their turn to think of a new word and act it out. Keep taking turns and enjoy the game!

tips_text.eng:
* Make sure everyone gets a turn to act out words or phrases.  
* Remember to praise your teen for trying. 
* If your teen is struggling to guess, give them hints on what it could be.
* If the game is too easy, try more difficult words. 
* Remember to have fun and support each other!

tips_text.eng:
- Let your teen help choose the recipe or ingredients.
- Involve them in different things, like washing, measuring, cutting, and mixing.
- Praise their effort, even if the food isnâ€™t perfect.

ğŸ—£ï¸ Begin by sharing a story of your own. It might be something from today, a childhood memory, or a special moment.

â“ When youâ€™re done, invite your teen to ask questions or share a story of their own.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen with interest, ask questions, and show you care about what they say.

ğŸ’¡ If theyâ€™re unsure, ask something like â€œWhatâ€™s your favourite childhood memory?â€ or â€œWhatâ€™s a family tradition you enjoy?â€ They can even make up a story just for fun!

tips_text.eng: - Create a safe space for your teen to share their stories. They will share more with you if they feel like you wonâ€™t be upset with them.

ğŸ‰ You and your teen can plan a dream guestlist of famous people to invite to your party!

ğŸ“œ Each of you chooses five guests - they can be from the past or present.

ğŸ¤” Who would you invite? And do you think your guests would get along at the party?

rows.title: Two Truths, One Lie

intro_text.eng: Want a fun way to laugh and learn more about each other? Try this quick game of â€œTwo Truths and a Lieâ€ with your teen! ğŸ¤—

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ§  Think of three statements about yourself - two true and one thatâ€™s a lie.
- It can help to think about dreams, school, likes or dislikes. For example: *I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing.*

ğŸ—£ï¸ Share them with your teen and ask them to guess which one is the lie.

ğŸ˜² Did they guess right? Were they surprised?

ğŸ” Now let your teen try! Did you learn something new about each other?

rows.title: Superpower

intro_text.eng: Imagining superpowers is a fun way to spark creativity, play and connection with your teen!ğŸ¦¸â€â™€ï¸

steps_text.eng:

rows.title: The Interrupter

intro_text.eng: This fun and silly storytelling game is a great way to boost creativity and laughter with your teen! ğŸ’¥

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ“š Choose a storyteller to start making up a story.

ğŸ—£ï¸ Listeners can jump in anytime with any word, at any time.

ğŸ”„ The storyteller must include that word in their story - no matter how silly!

ğŸ‰ When the story ends, switch roles and let someone else be the storyteller!

rows.title: Get Active

intro_text.eng: Exercise is a great way to spend time together and it is so good for your health. Find a sport or exercise that both you and your teen want to do and try it out together! ğŸŒ±

steps_text.eng:
â° Even walking for 10 minutes a day is good for you. 

âš½ Together you can walk, run, play soccer, swim, dance, or do any other sport..

ğŸ† Together, think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns being the coach? Can there be a small, free reward, like getting to decide the next activity?

rows.title: This is Who I Am

intro_text.eng: Self-esteem is the way you value yourself, either in a positive or negative way. Helping your teen to have high self-esteem is a recipe for success! ğŸ†

steps_text.eng:
â­Share with your teen 3 things you like about yourself!

3ï¸âƒ£ Ask your teen to tell you 3 things they like about themselves. 
For example: I am great at treating others kindly. I am great at styling my hair. I am great at football. âš½

tips_text.eng: ğŸ“ If your teen does not feel comfortable sharing these, ask them to write them down.

rows.title: Traffic Lights

intro_text.eng: A group activity is a great way to bond with others! ğŸ’›

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ’¡ Choose one person to turn and face a wall. This will be the traffic officer. 

ğŸ Everyone else will begin the game at the other side of the room, or if you are outside, at a starting line. Set a long distance between the traffic officer and the players. 

ğŸ’š The game begins when the officer shouts â€œGreenâ€, and everyone can start moving towards the traffic officer at any speed they choose. 

ğŸ”´ The officer can shout â€œRed!â€ at any time, without looking behind them. When they shout this, everyone must stop and freeze! 

â¸ The officer turns around to see if everyone is frozen. If they see anyone moving, they have to send them back to the start line.

ğŸ† The winner is the first person to get to the officer without being sent back to the start.

ğŸ‘‘ The winner then becomes the traffic officer and you can play another round!

rows.title: Think Big, Think Small

intro_text.eng: Working towards big goals can be hard! Here is a way you can help your teen set new goals for the things they want to achieve. ğŸ‘‘

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ‘‘ Ask your teen to come up with three things that they are good at, and discuss what they did to become so good at them. For example: keeping their room neat, helping your family with housework, or playing a sport.

ğŸ† Next, ask your teen what they wish they were good at. 

ğŸ”‘ Remind them that it took work and practice to become good at the skills they have. They will have to do the same for any new goal.

â° Help your teen break down their goal and set up smaller goals they need to achieve to reach their greater goal.

tips_text.eng: ğŸ“ It is much easier to achieve a goal if you write it down! This way, you can be reminded of it as you work towards it.

rows.title: Take A Pause with your Teen

title.eng: Take A Pause with your Teen

intro_text.eng: Take a pause with your teen. This helps them deal with stress in a healthy way!

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ‘‚ Sit down together and close your eyes. Listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. 

â­ Take 5 more deep breaths.

ğŸ‘€ When you are ready, open your eyes again. Do you feel any different? 

â¸ Ask your teen what it was like to take a pause. Listen and accept whatever they say about it.

rows.title: Name That Tune

intro_text.eng: Listening to music is a great way to lower your stress and have fun with your family. ğŸ’š

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ“» Gather your family members and choose one person to play, sing or hum a song.

â“ Everyone else must guess the name and artist of the song.

ğŸ‰ The first one to guess it right becomes the next person to sing or play a song. 

ğŸ”„ Keep going around until everyone has been able to play their favourite song and let the rest hear.

rows.title: Whatâ€™s New?

intro_text.eng: Learning is fun! ğŸ“

steps_text.eng:
â“ Ask your teen to think of a new, fun skill you could learn together. 
- For example: keeping a ball in the air with your foot, juggling, making soup, moonwalking, whistling, saying the alphabet backwards, learning all the countries in Africa. 

ğŸ”„ Take turns trying out the new skill.  Make sure to praise each other and learn and play together!

ğŸ’› Approach learning the skill in a kind and fun way, and do not judge your teen or yourself for your ability in the skill.

rows.title: Yes, No or Maybe

intro_text.eng: Are you tired of hearing your teen say yes, no, or maybe to all of your questions? Turn your chat into a game, and donâ€™t allow one-word answers. ğŸˆ

steps_text.eng:
â­ Take turns asking each other questions. The only rule is that you cannot use one-word responses, such as Yes, No, Maybe, Fine, and Okay.
âš½ You can ask about things your teen likes or what they did today. For example, how was your day? What are you excited for? Is there anything worrying you?
ğŸ”„ It is important to let your teen ask a question as well. Trust is built when your teen can see that you are also sharing your life with them, and not only trying to learn about their life.

rows.title: Secret Handshake

intro_text.eng:
Letâ€™s make a special, fun, and unique handshake that only you and your child share ğŸ‘‹  

This isnâ€™t just about having fun - it helps build your childâ€™s confidence and teamwork skills while creating a special tradition you both can enjoy. âœ…

steps_text.eng:
ğŸ”¶ First, sit down together and talk about the kind of handshake you want. Should it be quick and silly, or cool and complicated? Itâ€™s totally up to you! 

ğŸµ You can start by choosing a few simple moves like clapping patterns, high fives, fist bumps, or snapping fingers.

ğŸ”„ Next, practice adding different steps. Maybe a spin, a shoulder tap, or even a fun dance move. The more creative and playful, the better!

ğŸ’› Once youâ€™ve mastered your moves, make your secret handshake a part of your routine! Use it as a fun greeting after school, or anytime you want to feel that special connection.

rows.title: Bao

intro_text.eng: Playing Bao can be a fun way to spend time with your teen. They will be excited to play a game with you and not only do chores.

steps_text.eng:
ğŸª£ Draw a board in the sand â€” 2 rows of 8 small holes and 2 big holes at the ends.
ğŸŒ± Find 32 small seeds or stones.

1ï¸âƒ£ Put 2 seeds in each small hole. Leave the big holes empty.
2ï¸âƒ£ Choose who starts. Take the 2 seeds from one hole and drop them one by one into the next holes going around. Then itâ€™s the other personâ€™s turn.
3ï¸âƒ£ Keep playing until no one can move. The person with more seeds in their big hole wins! ğŸ†

tips_text.eng:
- If you played before, tell your teen stories about you playing the game.
- Play a practice game to help your teen understand the rules.
- Celebrate your teenâ€™s successes and encourage them to keep practising, even if they do not win right away.
